concept.title: Firewalls and Ports
concept.shortdesc: Make sure your port settings are configured correctly for firewalls.

section.p: There are several different port settings that need to be considered when using firewalls:

ul.li:
Port that the cache server listens on. This is configurable using the cache-server element in cache.xml, on the CacheServer class in Java APIs, and as a command line option to the gfsh start server command.
By default, if not otherwise specified, clients and servers discover each other on a pre-defined port (40404) on the localhost.

Locator port. clients can use the locator to automatically discover cache servers. The locator port is configurable as a command-line option to the gfsh start locator command. Locators are used in the peer-to-peer cache deployments to discover other processes. They can be used by clients to locate servers as an alternative to configuring clients with a collection of server addresses and ports.
By default, if not otherwise specified, locators use the default multicast port 10334.
Since locators start up the distributed system, locators must also have their ephemeral port range and TCP port accessible to other members through the firewall.

For clients, you configure the client to connect to servers using the client's pool configuration. The client's pool configuration has two options: you can create a pool with either a list of server elements or a list of locator elements. For each element, you specify the host and port. The ports specified must be made accessible through your firewall.

title.b: Limiting Ephemeral Ports for Peer-to-Peer Membership

section.p: By default, assigns ephemeral ports, that is, temporary ports assigned from a designated range, which can encompass a large number of possible ports. When a firewall is present, the ephemeral port range usually must be limited to a much smaller number, for example six. If you are configuring P2P communications through a firewall, you must also set each the tcp port for each process and ensure that UDP traffic is allowed through the firewall.

title.b: Properties for Firewall and Port Configuration in Multi-Site (WAN) Configurations

section.p: Each gateway receiver uses a port to listen for incoming communication from one or more gateway senders communication between sites. The full range of port values for gateway receivers must be made accessible within the firewall from across the WAN.
This table contains properties potentially involved in firewall behavior, with a brief description of each property. Click on a property name for a link to the reference topic.

entry.p: Hostname or IP address of the gateway receiver used by gateway senders to connect.
List of locators (and their ports) that are available on the remote WAN site.
start-port and end-port (cache.xml) or --start-port and --end-port parameters to the gfsh start gateway receiver command
Port range that the gateway receiver can use to listen for gateway sender communication.

row.entry: not set Each gateway receiver uses a single port to accept connections from gateway senders in other systems. However, the configuration of a gateway receiver specifies a range of possible port values to use. selects an available port from the specified range when the gateway receiver starts. Configure your firewall so that the full range of possible port values is accessible by gateway senders from across the WAN.
